outputs.output_descr:
As the regulator, the IMC in the most recent past had been forced and obliged to take stringent remedial actions against some media houses that are faulting the press freedom granted in the country. 
Additionally, though today's media scene has evolved beyond recognition, some aspects of the media industry still bear the scars. Despite several attempts and efforts by civil society, the FOI bill has still not been enacted into law and most practicing journalists are untrained. The print media in particular, is hampered by the lack of basic technology and access to such simple tools as computers, tape recorders, office furniture and stationery. Newsprint is expensive; the five printing presses in Freetown are expected to handle over 20 papers daily and distribution is in the hands of the Newspaper Vendors' Association who exercise enormous influence over the content of papers, particularly the front pages. Perhaps the most dramatic growth has taken place in the electronic media where the number of local and community radio stations now registered with the Independent Media Commission (IMC) numbers more than 50.
